headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Final Arguments In Fani Willis Disqualification Hearing. Aired 2:30-3p ET

utterances.speaker: JUDGE SCOTT MCAFEE, FULTON COUNTY SUPERIOR COURT
utterances.sentences: No. ABBATE

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: That's fine.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: All right. Thank you, Your Honor.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: All right. Let's take a quick five. And we'll be back 2Thank you.

utterances.speaker: JESSICA DEAN, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: All right. You have been listening to the final arguments there in that disqualification hearing down in Fulton County, hearing from attorneys for the defendants in the broader case.Just to remind everyone, this is a hearing within that case surrounded on that prosecutor, Fani Willis.

utterances.speaker: BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. Some really interesting arguments to get into.Harry MacDougald, who was just speaking, now he's an attorney for Jeffrey Clark, one of Trump's more than a dozen co-defendants, describing what he sees as a conflict of interests for Fani Willis as an irreparable stain, as a bonfire of conflicts of interests. Asking what message he thinks would be sent if they were not disqualified. They, being the district attorney, Fani Willis, and the entire team, Nathan Wade, included. Let's bring in CNN's Laura Coates, who has been watching and taking notes alongside us this entire time.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: I've been learning from Laura as we go.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Asking questions.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes, so initially, a big part of the discussion that we heard from the defense team had to do with the question of whether there was an actual conflict of interest or the appearance of conflict of interest.The defense there, at one point, John Merchant, part of the defense team for Mike Roman, seemed to argue that they didn't need to prove actual conflict, but rather just the appearance of conflict of interests. What did you make of those arguments, of the arguments overall? LAURA COATES, CNN ANCHOR & CNN CHIEF LEGAL ANALYST: Well, first, on the arguments overall, qualitatively, what a different experience this afternoon has been compared to the sort of meandering, trying to figure out what the theory of the case was going to be earlier. A lot of testimony, a lot of back-and-forth. This was a streamlined approach based on what they would like the judge to know. Now, remember, the most persuasive arguments are based on primacy and recency. The first thing I told you and the last thing I told you. But don't forget everything in between. And they're going to come here at the last part talking about the idea of forensic misconduct. You heard that all day today. What does that mean? Well, there's two primary ways to disqualify somebody. Either you had a financial benefit that makes it such that the defense cannot have an actual fair trial or you have a personal stake in the outcome of the case. They are suggesting that this is a blurred line, on one hand, that she is financially benefitting, that they cannot be considered to be truthful at all, and the judge cannot, what they say, credit their testimony, that they are lying somehow. And therefore, you can't believe anything they have to say. Even going so far as to say they concocted the whole cash theory. We're going to figure out how to make this case go away. Then there's the idea of the personal stake, meaning whatever the outcome of this is, I'm so deeply invested based on my personal or political ambition. But there was this huge moment that I thought was so fascinating. And that was coming from the attorney for Donald Trump, Mr. Sadow. He went right into the idea of the church speech.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Just a moment. When Fani Willis went to a historically black church and she spoke about and intimated the reason they are focusing on Nathan Wade as but one member of the team as opposed to all others, was because he was a black man.They want to disqualify him. They wanted to undermine his credentials. They wanted to mask him professionally. This was a moment with the actual attorneys took high interest in. They suggest that she tainted the jury pool by making that statement. And they play out the timing of this. Forget their relationship. The timing of when she made these statements. She had not yet responded in her pleadings to the judge to the other filings in the motion. She wanted to have this moment. And the judges -- or the judge is asking the question, is the ethical allegation that you were raising enough to disqualify. They want them to believe it actually is. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Well, yet again, what an appearance by Fani Willis.(LAUGHTER) (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Remember the last time she came into a courtroom, right, and all of a sudden, she appears ready to testify.They actually pointed out her testimony in this latest argument to suggest that she was so defiant that she was kind of doing the idea, "me thinks the lady doth protest too much," that she wanted to focus on everything but. And here was a moment. They've been focusing on a relationship. They want to suggest that they were being cutesy. They were -- it was Wade and Willis who wanted to focus on sexual interactions as distraction to win romance actually began. But remember, this judge asked a really important question. He asked, well, what is the personal interest? That was a first question out of the gate, which made me think to myself, well, if the judge is asking after all your arguments, what is the personal interest, you've got a problem. The second really important one was about immateriality. Remember that point? He said, is there an immateriality requirement? This was the gum part. This was the gum part.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: This was when we're all thinking, well, if I give you a stick of gum, like in my disqualified? You might need the gum. I might have the gum. I want to give the gum.That was a really important point because they had an opportunity to say, no, I'm not going to just strain credulity and tell you, yes, everything is fair game. Materiality goes to the idea of, OK, is what is being exchanged or given enough to disqualify you because the defendant can't have a fair trial. A stick of gum, come on, a coffee, come on. But they pointed to her statements and signing off on limitations of what she got. As we were going, I know.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You knew it, yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: A hundred dollars.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes. She signed documents. This is Richard Rice, Robert Cheeley's defense attorney, saying that she -- she did not receive any gifts, none in excess of a hundred dollars.The defense team here is pointing to some $9,000 or so dollars that they believe were unaccounted for in these trips that Nathan Wade and Fani Willis took. I mean, it isn't that glaring that there's 9,000 bucks that they don't really know where it went?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The devil is in the details. And they think is glaring. And they also think that the fact that this argument seems to be, yes, but I paid you back. So all's well, that ends well? That's going to be enough?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: When reality -- they pointed out, what if you were in a money- laundering case? Now, of course, Fani Willis is known for one of the biggest RICO cases in Georgia.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: She's litigating it right now. She has this other huge one involving the former president of the United States. She's a seasoned prosecutor. She knows full well, if someone were and I say, oh, hold on, you can't prosecute me because I paid that back, that would be laughable.They're making that same argument now to suggest, you can't just say I paid this person back. It's fine. But you still have to connect this very important set of dots. The money that she is spending, yes, may come from the salary from being an elected official and employee but is that the motivation for why this case is happening? (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: -- updating that?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: No. Keep going.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: No. Is that why it's happening? Is that -- are you -- are you suggesting, which is what they're trying to argue, that they went into this entire case because they wanted to sustain a romantic relationship and use these indictments as a kind of legal beard, right?To say, hey, you know what, how can we hang out more? How can we road trip to Nashville? I know were going to indict the former president of United States and 17 other people. That's what they're trying to suggest. But make no mistake. They want this judge to find, if there was an ethical violation, that's enough risk qualification, and that is what they have to prove to this judge.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: But we also have former deputy assistant attorney general, Harry Litman, with us.It appears that proceedings are soon to get underway, so we'll cut to it. But, Harry, quickly, your impressions of these arguments from the defense? HARRY LITMAN, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY: Yes. They are just very long on accusations of romantic activity, but very short on what they need, either financial conflict of interests. It's an interesting point that Laura just raised about this $100. But that's not the same as what you need to say there's a bona fide financial conflict of interest and that's why they're doing it. I think Laura's discussion just -- just showed why that's so tenuous. And then otherwise, in some way, what if you don't have confidence in her, Judge, or maybe you don't credit everything she said, that also is not the standard. So I think, basically, they've -- they've been very salacious and tough on Fani Willis, but haven't presented anything to really give McAfee a reason to actually disqualify her, which is a very extreme move obviously.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: All right, Harry, stick with us.Laura, stay with us. Let's go back into the court, the courtroom, and listen.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Wait. You're you making an argument? I should make inference based. Now these would be attorney-client privileges, or communications then.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: She's communicating with Mr. Partridge about what her upcoming testimony is. That's why she's hired him. And you're telling me I should infer things based on her communications to him?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Are you talking about Ms. Ventura?

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: Let's go back -- let's go back to that. Show me how.

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Show you how --

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: So I think the first one decided was Battle v. the State. Certainly a conflict of interests or the appearance of impropriety can be the grounds for disqualification.Well, there are a number of these cases that seemed to exclusively rely on the appearance of impropriety,

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: Right. But what --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: But they -- they acknowledge that there's some ambiguity here, that sometimes Wentworth -- Wentworth gets cited of Ventura and we've got this quote that comes up where it's just they only cite to an actual conflict that must be involved.They -- they acknowledged the ambiguity. You're saying there's no ambiguity whatsoever?

utterances.speaker: ABBATE
utterances.sentences: I'm -- I am saying that. And why -- why I am saying that, why I submit that to the court is, in all of those cases, they do reference the appearance of an impropriety, but they reference that because they also find there's an actual conflict in each one of those cases.

utterances.speaker: MCAFEE
utterances.sentences: So your position would be in your review of the case law, there's never been an appellate opinion that relied only on an appearance of propriety.
